scenes.location: An apartment in the Duke's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Escalus.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: My lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Of government the properties to unfold Would seem in me t' affect speech and discourse, Since I am put to know that your own science Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice My strength can give you. Then no more remains But that, to your sufficiency, as your worth is able, And let them work. The nature of our people, Our city's institutions, and the terms For common justice, you're as pregnant in As art and practice hath enriched any That we remember. There is our commission, From which we would not have you warp.-Call hither, I say, bid come before us, Angelo. What figure of us think you he will bear? For you must know we have with special soul Elected him our absence to supply; Lent him our terror, drest him with our love, And given his deputation all the organs Of our own power. What think you of it?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: If any in Vienna be of worth To undergo such ample grace and honour, It is Lord Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Look where he comes.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Always obedient to your Grace's will, I come to know your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Angelo, There is a kind of character in thy life That to th' observer doth thy history Fully unfold. Thyself and thy belongings Are not thine own so proper as to waste Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee. Heaven doth with us as we with torches do, Not light them for themselves; for if our virtues Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike As if we had them not. Spirits are not finely touched But to fine issues; nor nature never lends The smallest scruple of her excellence But, like a thrifty goddess, she determines Herself the glory of a creditor, Both thanks and use. But I do bend my speech To one that can my part in him advertise. Hold, therefore, Angelo. In our remove be thou at full ourself. Mortality and mercy in Vienna Live in thy tongue and heart. Old Escalus, Though first in question, is thy secondary. Take thy commission.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Now, good my lord, Let there be some more test made of my metal, Before so noble and so great a figure Be stamped upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: No more evasion. We have with a leavened and prepared choice Proceeded to you; therefore take your honours. Our haste from hence is of so quick condition That it prefers itself, and leaves unquestioned Matters of needful value. We shall write to you, As time and our concernings shall importune, How it goes with us; and do look to know What doth befall you here. So, fare you well. To th' hopeful execution do I leave you Of your commissions.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Yet give leave, my lord, That we may bring you something on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: My haste may not admit it; Nor need you, on mine honour, have to do With any scruple. Your scope is as mine own, So to enforce or qualify the laws As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand; I'll privily away. I love the people, But do not like to stage me to their eyes. Though it do well, I do not relish well Their loud applause and _Aves_ vehement; Nor do I think the man of safe discretion That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: The heavens give safety to your purposes!

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Lead forth and bring you back in happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I thank you. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I shall desire you, sir, to give me leave To have free speech with you; and it concerns me To look into the bottom of my place. A power I have, but of what strength and nature I am not yet instructed.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: 'Tis so with me. Let us withdraw together, And we may soon our satisfaction have Touching that point.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I'll wait upon your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: If the Duke, with the other dukes, come not to composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the dukes fall upon the King.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Heaven grant us its peace, but not the King of Hungary's!

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Thou conclud'st like the sanctimonious pirate that went to sea with the ten commandments, but scraped one out of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: "Thou shalt not steal"?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Ay, that he razed.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Why, 'twas a commandment to command the captain and all the rest from their functions! They put forth to steal. There's not a soldier of us all that, in the thanksgiving before meat, do relish the petition well that prays for peace.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: I never heard any soldier dislike it.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I believe thee; for I think thou never wast where grace was said.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: No? A dozen times at least.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: What? In metre?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: In any proportion or in any language.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: I think, or in any religion.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Ay, why not? Grace is grace, despite of all controversy; as, for example, thou thyself art a wicked villain, despite of all grace.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Well, there went but a pair of shears between us.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I grant, as there may between the lists and the velvet. Thou art the list.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: And thou the velvet. Thou art good velvet; thou'rt a three-piled piece, I warrant thee. I had as lief be a list of an English kersey as be piled, as thou art piled, for a French velvet. Do I speak feelingly now?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I think thou dost, and indeed, with most painful feeling of thy speech. I will, out of thine own confession, learn to begin thy health; but, whilst I live, forget to drink after thee.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: I think I have done myself wrong, have I not?

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Yes, that thou hast, whether thou art tainted or free.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation comes! I have purchased as many diseases under her roof as come to-

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: To what, I pray?

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: To three thousand dolours a year.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Ay, and more.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: A French crown more.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Thou art always figuring diseases in me, but thou art full of error; I am sound.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Nay, not, as one would say, healthy, but so sound as things that are hollow. Thy bones are hollow. Impiety has made a feast of thee.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: How now, which of your hips has the most profound sciatica?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Well, well! There's one yonder arrested and carried to prison was worth five thousand of you all.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Who's that, I pray thee?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: Claudio to prison? 'Tis not so.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Nay, but I know 'tis so. I saw him arrested, saw him carried away; and, which is more, within these three days his head to be chopped off.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: But, after all this fooling, I would not have it so. Art thou sure of this?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: I am too sure of it. And it is for getting Madam Julietta with child.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Believe me, this may be. He promised to meet me two hours since, and he was ever precise in promise-keeping.

dialogues.speaker: Second Gentleman
dialogues.line: Besides, you know, it draws something near to the speech we had to such a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: First Gentleman
dialogues.line: But most of all agreeing with the proclamation.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Away! Let's go learn the truth of it.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what with the gallows, and what with poverty, I am custom-shrunk. How now? What's the news with you?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Yonder man is carried to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Well, what has he done?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: A woman.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: But what's his offence?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Groping for trouts in a peculiar river.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What? Is there a maid with child by him?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: No, but there's a woman with maid by him. You have not heard of the proclamation, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What proclamation, man?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: All houses in the suburbs of Vienna must be plucked down.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: And what shall become of those in the city?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: They shall stand for seed. They had gone down too, but that a wise burgher put in for them.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: But shall all our houses of resort in the suburbs be pulled down?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: To the ground, mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Why, here's a change indeed in the commonwealth! What shall become of me?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Come, fear not you. Good counsellors lack no clients. Though you change your place, you need not change your trade. I'll be your tapster still. Courage, there will be pity taken on you. You that have worn your eyes almost out in the service, you will be considered.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: What's to do here, Thomas Tapster? Let's withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the Provost to prison. And there's Madam Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world? Bear me to prison, where I am committed.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I do it not in evil disposition, But from Lord Angelo by special charge.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thus can the demi-god Authority Make us pay down for our offence by weight. The words of heaven; on whom it will, it will; On whom it will not, so; yet still 'tis just.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Why, how now, Claudio? Whence comes this restraint?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty. As surfeit is the father of much fast, So every scope by the immoderate use Turns to restraint. Our natures do pursue, Like rats that ravin down their proper bane, A thirsty evil; and when we drink, we die.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: If I could speak so wisely under an arrest, I would send for certain of my creditors; and yet, to say the truth, I had as lief have the foppery of freedom as the morality of imprisonment. What's thy offence, Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: What but to speak of would offend again.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: What, is't murder?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Lechery?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Call it so.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Away, sir; you must go.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: One word, good friend.-Lucio, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: A hundred, if they'll do you any good. Is lechery so looked after?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract I got possession of Julietta's bed. You know the lady; she is fast my wife, Save that we do the denunciation lack Of outward order. This we came not to Only for propagation of a dower Remaining in the coffer of her friends, From whom we thought it meet to hide our love Till time had made them for us. But it chances The stealth of our most mutual entertainment With character too gross is writ on Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: With child, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Unhappily, even so. And the new deputy now for the Duke- Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newness, Or whether that the body public be A horse whereon the governor doth ride, Who, newly in the seat, that it may know He can command, lets it straight feel the spur; Whether the tyranny be in his place, Or in his eminence that fills it up, I stagger in-but this new governor Awakes me all the enrolled penalties Which have, like unscoured armour, hung by th' wall So long that nineteen zodiacs have gone round, And none of them been worn; and for a name Now puts the drowsy and neglected act Freshly on me. 'Tis surely for a name.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I warrant it is. And thy head stands so tickle on thy shoulders that a milkmaid, if she be in love, may sigh it off. Send after the Duke, and appeal to him.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I have done so, but he's not to be found. I prithee, Lucio, do me this kind service: This day my sister should the cloister enter, And there receive her approbation. Acquaint her with the danger of my state; Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him. I have great hope in that. For in her youth There is a prone and speechless dialect Such as moves men; beside, she hath prosperous art When she will play with reason and discourse, And well she can persuade.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I pray she may, as well for the encouragement of the like, which else would stand under grievous imposition, as for the enjoying of thy life, who I would be sorry should be thus foolishly lost at a game of tick-tack. I'll to her.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I thank you, good friend Lucio.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Come, officer, away.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: No, holy father, throw away that thought; Believe not that the dribbling dart of love Can pierce a complete bosom. Why I desire thee To give me secret harbour hath a purpose More grave and wrinkled than the aims and ends Of burning youth.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Thomas
dialogues.line: May your Grace speak of it?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: My holy sir, none better knows than you How I have ever loved the life removed, And held in idle price to haunt assemblies Where youth, and cost, a witless bravery keeps. I have delivered to Lord Angelo, A man of stricture and firm abstinence, My absolute power and place here in Vienna, And he supposes me travelled to Poland; For so I have strewed it in the common ear, And so it is received. Now, pious sir, You will demand of me why I do this?

dialogues.speaker: Friar Thomas
dialogues.line: Gladly, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: We have strict statutes and most biting laws, The needful bits and curbs to headstrong weeds, Which for this fourteen years we have let slip, Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave That goes not out to prey. Now, as fond fathers, Having bound up the threat'ning twigs of birch, Only to stick it in their children's sight For terror, not to use, in time the rod Becomes more mocked than feared: so our decrees, Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead, And liberty plucks justice by the nose, The baby beats the nurse, and quite athwart Goes all decorum.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Thomas
dialogues.line: It rested in your Grace To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased; And it in you more dreadful would have seemed Than in Lord Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I do fear, too dreadful. Sith 'twas my fault to give the people scope, 'Twould be my tyranny to strike and gall them For what I bid them do; for we bid this be done When evil deeds have their permissive pass And not the punishment. Therefore, indeed, my father, I have on Angelo imposed the office; Who may in th' ambush of my name strike home, And yet my nature never in the fight To do in slander. And to behold his sway, I will, as 'twere a brother of your order, Visit both prince and people. Therefore, I prithee, Supply me with the habit, and instruct me How I may formally in person bear Like a true friar. Moe reasons for this action At our more leisure shall I render you; Only, this one: Lord Angelo is precise; Stands at a guard with envy; scarce confesses That his blood flows or that his appetite Is more to bread than stone. Hence shall we see, If power change purpose, what our seemers be.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: And have you nuns no farther privileges?

dialogues.speaker: Francisca
dialogues.line: Are not these large enough?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Yes, truly; I speak not as desiring more, But rather wishing a more strict restraint Upon the sisterhood, the votarists of Saint Clare.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Ho! Peace be in this place!

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Who's that which calls?

dialogues.speaker: Francisca
dialogues.line: It is a man's voice. Gentle Isabella, Turn you the key, and know his business of him; You may, I may not; you are yet unsworn. When you have vowed, you must not speak with men But in the presence of the prioress; Then, if you speak, you must not show your face; Or if you show your face, you must not speak. He calls again. I pray you answer him.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Peace and prosperity! Who is't that calls?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Hail, virgin, if you be, as those cheek-roses Proclaim you are no less. Can you so stead me As bring me to the sight of Isabella, A novice of this place, and the fair sister To her unhappy brother Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Why "her unhappy brother"? let me ask, The rather for I now must make you know I am that Isabella, and his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you. Not to be weary with you, he's in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Woe me! For what?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: For that which, if myself might be his judge, He should receive his punishment in thanks: He hath got his friend with child.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Sir, make me not your story.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: 'Tis true. I would not, though 'tis my familiar sin With maids to seem the lapwing, and to jest, Tongue far from heart, play with all virgins so. I hold you as a thing enskied and sainted By your renouncement an immortal spirit, And to be talked with in sincerity, As with a saint.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: You do blaspheme the good in mocking me.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus: Your brother and his lover have embraced; As those that feed grow full, as blossoming time That from the seedness the bare fallow brings To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Someone with child by him? My cousin Juliet?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Is she your cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Adoptedly, as school-maids change their names By vain though apt affection.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: She it is.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, let him marry her!

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: This is the point. The Duke is very strangely gone from hence; Bore many gentlemen, myself being one, In hand, and hope of action; but we do learn, By those that know the very nerves of state, His givings-out were of an infinite distance From his true-meant design. Upon his place, And with full line of his authority, Governs Lord Angelo; a man whose blood Is very snow-broth; one who never feels The wanton stings and motions of the sense; But doth rebate and blunt his natural edge With profits of the mind, study and fast. He, to give fear to use and liberty, Which have for long run by the hideous law As mice by lions, hath picked out an act, Under whose heavy sense your brother's life Falls into forfeit. He arrests him on it, And follows close the rigour of the statute To make him an example. All hope is gone, Unless you have the grace by your fair prayer To soften Angelo. And that's my pith of business 'Twixt you and your poor brother.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Doth he so Seek his life?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Has censured him already; And, as I hear, the Provost hath a warrant For's execution.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Alas, what poor ability's in me To do him good?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Assay the power you have.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: My power? Alas, I doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Our doubts are traitors, And make us lose the good we oft might win By fearing to attempt. Go to Lord Angelo, And let him learn to know, when maidens sue, Men give like gods; but when they weep and kneel, All their petitions are as freely theirs As they themselves would owe them.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: But speedily.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I will about it straight; No longer staying but to give the Mother Notice of my affair. I humbly thank you. Commend me to my brother. Soon at night I'll send him certain word of my success.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I take my leave of you.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Good sir, adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: We must not make a scarecrow of the law, Setting it up to fear the birds of prey, And let it keep one shape till custom make it Their perch, and not their terror.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Ay, but yet Let us be keen, and rather cut a little Than fall and bruise to death. Alas, this gentleman, Whom I would save, had a most noble father. Let but your honour know, Whom I believe to be most strait in virtue, That, in the working of your own affections, Had time cohered with place, or place with wishing, Or that the resolute acting of your blood Could have attained th' effect of your own purpose, Whether you had not sometime in your life Erred in this point which now you censure him, And pulled the law upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: 'Tis one thing to be tempted, Escalus, Another thing to fall. I not deny The jury passing on the prisoner's life May in the sworn twelve have a thief or two Guiltier than him they try. What's open made to justice, That justice seizes. What knows the laws That thieves do pass on thieves? 'Tis very pregnant, The jewel that we find, we stoop and take 't, Because we see it; but what we do not see, We tread upon, and never think of it. You may not so extenuate his offence For I have had such faults; but rather tell me, When I that censure him do so offend, Let mine own judgement pattern out my death, And nothing come in partial. Sir, he must die.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Be it as your wisdom will.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Where is the Provost?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Here, if it like your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: See that Claudio Be executed by nine tomorrow morning. Bring him his confessor, let him be prepared, For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Well, heaven forgive him; and forgive us all. Some rise by sin, and some by virtue fall. Some run from brakes of vice, and answer none, And some condemned for a fault alone.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Come, bring them away. If these be good people in a commonweal that do nothing but use their abuses in common houses, I know no law. Bring them away.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: How now, sir, what's your name? And what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: If it please your honour, I am the poor Duke's constable, and my name is Elbow. I do lean upon justice, sir, and do bring in here before your good honour two notorious benefactors.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Benefactors? Well, what benefactors are they? Are they not malefactors?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: If it please your honour, I know not well what they are, but precise villains they are, that I am sure of, and void of all profanation in the world that good Christians ought to have.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: This comes off well. Here's a wise officer.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Go to. What quality are they of? Elbow is your name? Why dost thou not speak, Elbow?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: He cannot, sir. He's out at elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: What are you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: He, sir? A tapster, sir; parcel bawd; one that serves a bad woman; whose house, sir, was, as they say, plucked down in the suburbs; and now she professes a hot-house, which, I think is a very ill house too.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: How know you that?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: My wife, sir, whom I detest before heaven and your honour-

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: How? Thy wife?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, whom I thank heaven is an honest woman-

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Dost thou detest her therefore?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: I say, sir, I will detest myself also, as well as she, that this house, if it be not a bawd's house, it is pity of her life, for it is a naughty house.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: How dost thou know that, constable?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, by my wife, who, if she had been a woman cardinally given, might have been accused in fornication, adultery, and all uncleanliness there.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: By the woman's means?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, by Mistress Overdone's means; but as she spit in his face, so she defied him.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, if it please your honour, this is not so.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Prove it before these varlets here, thou honourable man, prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Do you hear how he misplaces?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, she came in great with child; and longing, saving your honour's reverence, for stewed prunes; sir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time stood, as it were, in a fruit dish, a dish of some threepence; your honours have seen such dishes; they are not china dishes, but very good dishes-

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Go to, go to. No matter for the dish, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: No, indeed, sir, not of a pin; you are therein in the right. But to the point. As I say, this Mistress Elbow, being, as I say, with child, and being great-bellied, and longing, as I said, for prunes; and having but two in the dish, as I said, Master Froth here, this very man, having eaten the rest, as I said, and, as I say, paying for them very honestly; for, as you know, Master Froth, I could not give you threepence again-

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: No, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Very well. You being then, if you be remembered, cracking the stones of the foresaid prunes-

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: Ay, so I did indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Why, very well. I telling you then, if you be remembered, that such a one and such a one were past cure of the thing you wot of, unless they kept very good diet, as I told you-

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: All this is true.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Why, very well then-

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Come, you are a tedious fool. To the purpose. What was done to Elbow's wife that he hath cause to complain of? Come me to what was done to her.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, your honour cannot come to that yet.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: No, sir, nor I mean it not.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honour's leave. And I beseech you, look into Master Froth here, sir, a man of fourscore pound a year; whose father died at Hallowmas-was't not at Hallowmas, Master Froth?

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: All-hallond Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Why, very well. I hope here be truths. He, sir, sitting, as I say, in a lower chair, sir-'twas in the Bunch of Grapes, where, indeed, you have a delight to sit, have you not?

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: I have so, because it is an open room, and good for winter.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Why, very well then. I hope here be truths.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: This will last out a night in Russia When nights are longest there. I'll take my leave, And leave you to the hearing of the cause; Hoping you'll find good cause to whip them all.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I think no less. Good morrow to your lordship. Now, sir, come on. What was done to Elbow's wife, once more?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Once, sir? There was nothing done to her once.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: I beseech you, sir, ask him what this man did to my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I beseech your honour, ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Well, sir, what did this gentleman to her?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I beseech you, sir, look in this gentleman's face. Good Master Froth, look upon his honour; 'tis for a good purpose.-Doth your honour mark his face?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, very well.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Nay, I beseech you, mark it well.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Well, I do so.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Doth your honour see any harm in his face?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Why, no.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I'll be supposed upon a book, his face is the worst thing about him. Good, then, if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth do the constable's wife any harm? I would know that of your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: He's in the right. Constable. What say you to it?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: First, an it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his mistress is a respected woman.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: By this hand, sir, his wife is a more respected person than any of us all.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Varlet, thou liest; thou liest, wicked varlet! The time is yet to come that she was ever respected with man, woman, or child.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, she was respected with him before he married with her.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Which is the wiser here, Justice or Iniquity? Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: O thou caitiff! O thou varlet! O thou wicked Hannibal! I respected with her before I was married to her? If ever I was respected with her, or she with me, let not your worship think me the poor Duke's officer. Prove this, thou wicked Hannibal, or I'll have mine action of battery on thee.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: If he took you a box o' th' ear, you might have your action of slander too.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Marry, I thank your good worship for it. What is't your worship's pleasure I shall do with this wicked caitiff?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Truly, officer, because he hath some offences in him that thou wouldst discover if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses till thou know'st what they are.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Marry, I thank your worship for it.-Thou seest, thou wicked varlet, now, what's come upon thee. Thou art to continue now, thou varlet, thou art to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Where were you born, friend?

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: Here in Vienna, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Are you of fourscore pounds a year?

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: Yes, an't please you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: So.  What trade are you of, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: A tapster, a poor widow's tapster.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Your mistress' name?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Mistress Overdone.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Hath she had any more than one husband?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Nine, sir; Overdone by the last.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Nine?-Come hither to me, Master Froth. Master Froth, I would not have you acquainted with tapsters; they will draw you, Master Froth, and you will hang them. Get you gone, and let me hear no more of you.

dialogues.speaker: Froth
dialogues.line: I thank your worship. For mine own part, I never come into any room in a taphouse but I am drawn in.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Well, no more of it, Master Froth. Farewell. Come you hither to me, Master tapster. What's your name, Master tapster?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Bum, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you; so that, in the beastliest sense, you are Pompey the great. Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey, howsoever you colour it in being a tapster, are you not? Come, tell me true, it shall be the better for you.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, I am a poor fellow that would live.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: How would you live, Pompey? By being a bawd? What do you think of the trade, Pompey? Is it a lawful trade?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: If the law would allow it, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: But the law will not allow it, Pompey; nor it shall not be allowed in Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the youth of the city?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: No, Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, in my poor opinion, they will to't then. If your worship will take order for the drabs and the knaves, you need not to fear the bawds.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: There is pretty orders beginning, I can tell you. It is but heading and hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: If you head and hang all that offend that way but for ten year together, you'll be glad to give out a commission for more heads. If this law hold in Vienna ten year, I'll rent the fairest house in it after threepence a bay. If you live to see this come to pass, say Pompey told you so.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Thank you, good Pompey; and, in requital of your prophecy, hark you: I advise you, let me not find you before me again upon any complaint whatsoever; no, not for dwelling where you do. If I do, Pompey, I shall beat you to your tent, and prove a shrewd Caesar to you. In plain dealing, Pompey, I shall have you whipped. So for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I thank your worship for your good counsel.  But I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better determine. Whip me? No, no; let carman whip his jade; The valiant heart's not whipped out of his trade.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Come hither to me, Master Elbow. Come hither, Master Constable. How long have you been in this place of constable?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Seven year and a half, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I thought, by the readiness in the office, you had continued in it sometime. You say seven years together?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: And a half, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Alas, it hath been great pains to you. They do you wrong to put you so oft upon't. Are there not men in your ward sufficient to serve it?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters. As they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it for some piece of money, and go through with all.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Look you bring me in the names of some six or seven, the most sufficient of your parish.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: To your worship's house, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: To my house. Fare you well. What's o'clock, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Justice
dialogues.line: Eleven, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I pray you home to dinner with me.

dialogues.speaker: Justice
dialogues.line: I humbly thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: It grieves me for the death of Claudio, But there's no remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Justice
dialogues.line: Lord Angelo is severe.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: It is but needful. Mercy is not itself that oft looks so; Pardon is still the nurse of second woe. But yet, Poor Claudio! There's no remedy. Come, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: He's hearing of a cause. He will come straight. I'll tell him of you.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Pray you do. I'll know His pleasure, may be he will relent. Alas, He hath but as offended in a dream; All sects, all ages, smack of this vice, and he To die for 't!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Now, what's the matter, Provost?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Is it your will Claudio shall die tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Did not I tell thee yea? Hadst thou not order? Why dost thou ask again?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Lest I might be too rash. Under your good correction, I have seen When, after execution, judgement hath Repented o'er his doom.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Go to; let that be mine. Do you your office, or give up your place, And you shall well be spared.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I crave your honour's pardon. What shall be done, sir, with the groaning Juliet? She's very near her hour.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Dispose of her To some more fitter place; and that with speed.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Here is the sister of the man condemned Desires access to you.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Hath he a sister?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord, a very virtuous maid, And to be shortly of a sisterhood, If not already.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well, let her be admitted. See you the fornicatress be removed; Let her have needful but not lavish means; There shall be order for it.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Save your honour!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Stay a little while.  You are welcome. What's your will?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I am a woeful suitor to your honour, Please but your honour hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well, what's your suit?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: There is a vice that most I do abhor, And most desire should meet the blow of justice; For which I would not plead, but that I must; For which I must not plead, but that I am At war 'twixt will and will not.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well, the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I have a brother is condemned to die; I do beseech you, let it be his fault, And not my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Heaven give thee moving graces.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Condemn the fault, and not the actor of it? Why, every fault's condemned ere it be done. Mine were the very cipher of a function To find the faults whose fine stands in record, And let go by the actor.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O just but severe law! I had a brother, then. Heaven keep your honour!

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Give't not o'er so. To him again, entreat him, Kneel down before him, hang upon his gown; You are too cold. If you should need a pin, You could not with more tame a tongue desire it. To him, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Must he needs die?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Maiden, no remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Yes, I do think that you might pardon him, And neither heaven nor man grieve at the mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I will not do't.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: But can you if you would?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Look, what I will not, that I cannot do.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: But might you do't, and do the world no wrong, If so your heart were touched with that remorse As mine is to him?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: He's sentenced, 'tis too late.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: You are too cold.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Too late? Why, no. I that do speak a word May call it back again. Well, believe this: No ceremony that to great ones longs, Not the king's crown, nor the deputed sword, The marshal's truncheon, nor the judge's robe, Become them with one half so good a grace As mercy does. If he had been as you, and you as he, You would have slipped like him, but he like you Would not have been so stern.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Pray you be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I would to heaven I had your potency, And you were Isabel! Should it then be thus? No; I would tell what 'twere to be a judge And what a prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Ay, touch him; there's the vein.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Your brother is a forfeit of the law, And you but waste your words.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Alas, alas! Why, all the souls that were were forfeit once, And He that might the vantage best have took Found out the remedy. How would you be If He, which is the top of judgement, should But judge you as you are? O, think on that, And mercy then will breathe within your lips, Like man new made.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Be you content, fair maid. It is the law, not I, condemns your brother. Were he my kinsman, brother, or my son, It should be thus with him. He must die tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Tomorrow? O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him! He's not prepared for death. Even for our kitchens We kill the fowl of season. Shall we serve heaven With less respect than we do minister To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you. Who is it that hath died for this offence? There's many have committed it.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Ay, well said.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: The law hath not been dead, though it hath slept. Those many had not dared to do that evil If the first that did th' edict infringe Had answered for his deed. Now 'tis awake, Takes note of what is done, and, like a prophet, Looks in a glass that shows what future evils, Either now, or by remissness new conceived, And so in progress to be hatched and born, Are now to have no successive degrees, But, where they live, to end.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Yet show some pity.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I show it most of all when I show justice; For then I pity those I do not know, Which a dismissed offence would after gall, And do him right that, answering one foul wrong, Lives not to act another. Be satisfied; Your brother dies tomorrow; be content.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: So you must be the first that gives this sentence, And he that suffers. O, it is excellent To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous To use it like a giant.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: That's well said.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Could great men thunder As Jove himself does, Jove would ne'er be quiet, For every pelting petty officer Would use his heaven for thunder. Nothing but thunder. Merciful Heaven, Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt Splits the unwedgeable and gnarled oak, Than the soft myrtle. But man, proud man, Dressed in a little brief authority, Most ignorant of what he's most assured, His glassy essence, like an angry ape Plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven As makes the angels weep; who, with our spleens, Would all themselves laugh mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: O, to him, to him, wench! He will relent; He's coming. I perceive 't.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Pray heaven she win him.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: We cannot weigh our brother with ourself. Great men may jest with saints; 'tis wit in them, But in the less, foul profanation.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Thou'rt i' th' right, girl; more o' that.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: That in the captain's but a choleric word Which in the soldier is flat blasphemy.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Art advised o' that? More on't.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Why do you put these sayings upon me?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Because authority, though it err like others, Hath yet a kind of medicine in itself That skins the vice o' th' top. Go to your bosom, Knock there, and ask your heart what it doth know That's like my brother's fault. If it confess A natural guiltiness such as is his, Let it not sound a thought upon your tongue Against my brother's life.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: She speaks, and 'tis such sense That my sense breeds with it.  Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Gentle my lord, turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I will bethink me. Come again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Hark how I'll bribe you. Good my lord, turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: How? Bribe me?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ay, with such gifts that heaven shall share with you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: You had marred all else.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Not with fond shekels of the tested gold, Or stones, whose rates are either rich or poor As fancy values them, but with true prayers, That shall be up at heaven and enter there Ere sunrise, prayers from preserved souls, From fasting maids, whose minds are dedicate To nothing temporal.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well; come to me tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Go to, 'tis well; away.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Heaven keep your honour safe.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Amen. For I am that way going to temptation, Where prayers cross.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: At what hour tomorrow Shall I attend your lordship?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: At any time 'fore noon.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Save your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: From thee, even from thy virtue! What's this? What's this? Is this her fault or mine? The tempter or the tempted, who sins most, ha? Not she; nor doth she tempt; but it is I That, lying by the violet in the sun, Do as the carrion does, not as the flower, Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be That modesty may more betray our sense Than woman's lightness? Having waste ground enough, Shall we desire to raze the sanctuary And pitch our evils there? O, fie, fie, fie! What dost thou, or what art thou, Angelo? Dost thou desire her foully for those things That make her good? O, let her brother live. Thieves for their robbery have authority When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her, That I desire to hear her speak again And feast upon her eyes? What is't I dream on? O cunning enemy, that, to catch a saint, With saints dost bait thy hook! Most dangerous Is that temptation that doth goad us on To sin in loving virtue. Never could the strumpet With all her double vigour, art, and nature, Once stir my temper, but this virtuous maid Subdues me quite. Ever till now When men were fond, I smiled and wondered how.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Hail to you, Provost, so I think you are.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I am the Provost. What's your will, good friar?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Bound by my charity and my blessed order, I come to visit the afflicted spirits Here in the prison. Do me the common right To let me see them, and to make me know The nature of their crimes, that I may minister To them accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I would do more than that, if more were needful. Look, here comes one, a gentlewoman of mine, Who, falling in the flaws of her own youth, Hath blistered her report. She is with child, And he that got it, sentenced: a young man More fit to do another such offence Than die for this.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: When must he die?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: As I do think, tomorrow.  I have provided for you; stay a while And you shall be conducted.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Repent you, fair one, of the sin you carry?

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: I do; and bear the shame most patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I'll teach you how you shall arraign your conscience, And try your penitence, if it be sound Or hollowly put on.

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: I'll gladly learn.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Love you the man that wronged you?

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: Yes, as I love the woman that wronged him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: So then it seems your most offenceful act Was mutually committed?

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: Mutually.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Then was your sin of heavier kind than his.

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: I do confess it, and repent it, father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: 'Tis meet so, daughter; but lest you do repent As that the sin hath brought you to this shame, Which sorrow is always toward ourselves, not heaven, Showing we would not spare heaven as we love it, But as we stand in fear-

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: I do repent me as it is an evil, And take the shame with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There rest. Your partner, as I hear, must die tomorrow, And I am going with instruction to him. Grace go with you! _Benedicite!_

dialogues.speaker: Juliet
dialogues.line: Must die tomorrow? O, injurious love That respites me a life, whose very comfort Is still a dying horror!

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: 'Tis pity of him.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: When I would pray and think, I think and pray To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words, Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue, Anchors on Isabel. Heaven in my mouth, As if I did but only chew his name, And in my heart the strong and swelling evil Of my conception. The state whereon I studied Is, like a good thing being often read, Grown sere and tedious; yea, my gravity, Wherein-let no man hear me-I take pride, Could I with boot change for an idle plume Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form, How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit, Wrench awe from fools, and tie the wiser souls To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood. Let's write good angel on the devil's horn. 'Tis not the devil's crest. How now, who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Teach her the way. O heavens, Why does my blood thus muster to my heart, Making both it unable for itself And dispossessing all my other parts Of necessary fitness? So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons, Come all to help him, and so stop the air By which he should revive. And even so The general subject to a well-wished king Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love Must needs appear offence. How now, fair maid?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I am come to know your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: That you might know it, would much better please me Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Even so. Heaven keep your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Yet may he live a while. And, it may be, As long as you or I. Yet he must die.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Under your sentence?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Yea.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: When, I beseech you? That in his reprieve, Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted That his soul sicken not.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Ha! Fie, these filthy vices! It were as good To pardon him that hath from nature stolen A man already made, as to remit Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image In stamps that are forbid. 'Tis all as easy Falsely to take away a life true made As to put metal in restrained means To make a false one.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Say you so? Then I shall pose you quickly. Which had you rather, that the most just law Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him, Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness As she that he hath stained?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Sir, believe this: I had rather give my body than my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I talk not of your soul. Our compelled sins Stand more for number than for accompt.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: How say you?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll not warrant that, for I can speak Against the thing I say. Answer to this: I, now the voice of the recorded law, Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life. Might there not be a charity in sin To save this brother's life?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Please you to do't, I'll take it as a peril to my soul; It is no sin at all, but charity.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul, Were equal poise of sin and charity.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: That I do beg his life, if it be sin, Heaven let me bear it. You granting of my suit, If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer To have it added to the faults of mine, And nothing of your answer.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Nay, but hear me. Your sense pursues not mine. Either you are ignorant, Or seem so, crafty; and that's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good, But graciously to know I am no better.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright When it doth tax itself, as these black masks Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder Than beauty could, displayed. But mark me; To be received plain, I'll speak more gross. Your brother is to die.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: So.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: And his offence is so, as it appears, Accountant to the law upon that pain.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: True.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Admit no other way to save his life- As I subscribe not that, nor any other, But, in the loss of question, that you, his sister, Finding yourself desired of such a person Whose credit with the judge, or own great place, Could fetch your brother from the manacles Of the all-binding law; and that there were No earthly mean to save him but that either You must lay down the treasures of your body To this supposed, or else to let him suffer, What would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: As much for my poor brother as myself. That is, were I under the terms of death, Th' impression of keen whips I'd wear as rubies, And strip myself to death as to a bed That longing have been sick for, ere I'd yield My body up to shame.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Then must your brother die.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: And 'twere the cheaper way. Better it were a brother died at once Than that a sister, by redeeming him, Should die for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence That you have slandered so?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ignominy in ransom and free pardon Are of two houses. Lawful mercy Is nothing kin to foul redemption.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You seemed of late to make the law a tyrant, And rather proved the sliding of your brother A merriment than a vice.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, pardon me, my lord. It oft falls out, To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean. I something do excuse the thing I hate For his advantage that I dearly love.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: We are all frail.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Else let my brother die, If not a feodary but only he Owe and succeed by weakness.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Nay, women are frail too.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves, Which are as easy broke as they make forms. Women?-Help, heaven! Men their creation mar In profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail; For we are soft as our complexions are, And credulous to false prints.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I think it well. And from this testimony of your own sex, Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger Than faults may shake our frames, let me be bold. I do arrest your words. Be that you are, That is, a woman. If you be more, you're none. If you be one, as you are well expressed By all external warrants, show it now By putting on the destined livery.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I have no tongue but one. Gentle my lord, Let me intreat you speak the former language.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Plainly conceive, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: My brother did love Juliet, And you tell me that he shall die for 't.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I know your virtue hath a license in't, Which seems a little fouler than it is, To pluck on others.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Believe me, on mine honour, My words express my purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ha! Little honour to be much believed, And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming! I will proclaim thee, Angelo, look for't. Sign me a present pardon for my brother Or with an outstretched throat I'll tell the world aloud What man thou art.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Who will believe thee, Isabel? My unsoiled name, th' austereness of my life, My vouch against you, and my place i' th' state Will so your accusation overweigh That you shall stifle in your own report, And smell of calumny. I have begun, And now I give my sensual race the rein. Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite; Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes That banish what they sue for. Redeem thy brother By yielding up thy body to my will; Or else he must not only die the death, But thy unkindness shall his death draw out To ling'ring sufferance. Answer me tomorrow, Or, by the affection that now guides me most, I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you, Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this, Who would believe me? O perilous mouths, That bear in them one and the self-same tongue Either of condemnation or approof, Bidding the law make curtsy to their will, Hooking both right and wrong to th' appetite, To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother. Though he hath fall'n by prompture of the blood, Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour That, had he twenty heads to tender down On twenty bloody blocks, he'd yield them up Before his sister should her body stoop To such abhorred pollution. Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die. More than our brother is our chastity. I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request, And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: The miserable have no other medicine But only hope. I have hope to live, and am prepared to die.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be absolute for death. Either death or life Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life: If I do lose thee, I do lose a thing That none but fools would keep. A breath thou art, Servile to all the skyey influences That dost this habitation where thou keep'st Hourly afflict. Merely, thou art death's fool; For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun, And yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble; For all th' accommodations that thou bear'st Are nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant; For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork Of a poor worm. Thy best of rest is sleep, And that thou oft provok'st, yet grossly fear'st Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself; For thou exists on many a thousand grains That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not; For what thou hast not, still thou striv'st to get, And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou art not certain; For thy complexion shifts to strange effects After the moon. If thou art rich, thou'rt poor; For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows, Thou bear'st thy heavy riches but a journey, And death unloads thee. Friend hast thou none; For thine own bowels which do call thee sire, The mere effusion of thy proper loins, Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age, But as it were an after-dinner's sleep Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich, Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this That bears the name of life? Yet in this life Lie hid more thousand deaths; yet death we fear, That makes these odds all even.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: I humbly thank you. To sue to live, I find I seek to die, And seeking death, find life. Let it come on.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: What ho! Peace here; grace and good company!

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Who's there? Come in. The wish deserves a welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Most holy sir, I thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: My business is a word or two with Claudio.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: And very welcome. Look, signior, here's your sister.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Provost, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: As many as you please.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Bring me to hear them speak, where I may be concealed.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Now, sister, what's the comfort?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Why, As all comforts are, most good, most good indeed. Lord Angelo, having affairs to heaven, Intends you for his swift ambassador, Where you shall be an everlasting leiger. Therefore your best appointment make with speed; Tomorrow you set on.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Is there no remedy?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: None, but such remedy as, to save a head, To cleave a heart in twain.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: But is there any?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Yes, brother, you may live. There is a devilish mercy in the judge, If you'll implore it, that will free your life, But fetter you till death.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Perpetual durance?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ay, just; perpetual durance; a restraint, Though all the world's vastidity you had, To a determined scope.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: But in what nature?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: In such a one as, you consenting to't, Would bark your honour from that trunk you bear, And leave you naked.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Let me know the point.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, I do fear thee, Claudio, and I quake, Lest thou a feverous life shouldst entertain, And six or seven winters more respect Than a perpetual honour. Dar'st thou die? The sense of death is most in apprehension; And the poor beetle that we tread upon In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great As when a giant dies.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Why give you me this shame? Think you I can a resolution fetch From flowery tenderness? If I must die, I will encounter darkness as a bride And hug it in mine arms.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: There spake my brother! There my father's grave Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die. Thou art too noble to conserve a life In base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy, Whose settled visage and deliberate word Nips youth i' th' head, and follies doth enew As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil. His filth within being cast, he would appear A pond as deep as hell.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: The precise Angelo?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell The damned'st body to invest and cover In precise guards! Dost thou think, Claudio, If I would yield him my virginity Thou mightst be freed?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O heavens, it cannot be.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Yes, he would give it thee, from this rank offence, So to offend him still. This night's the time That I should do what I abhor to name, Or else thou diest tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thou shalt not do't.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, were it but my life, I'd throw it down for your deliverance As frankly as a pin.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Thanks, dear Isabel.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Be ready, Claudio, for your death tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Yes. Has he affections in him That thus can make him bite the law by th' nose When he would force it? Sure it is no sin; Or of the deadly seven it is the least.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Which is the least?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: If it were damnable, he being so wise, Why would he for the momentary trick Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: What says my brother?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Death is a fearful thing.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: And shamed life a hateful.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Ay, but to die, and go we know not where; To lie in cold obstruction, and to rot; This sensible warm motion to become A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside In thrilling regions of thick-ribbed ice; To be imprisoned in the viewless winds And blown with restless violence round about The pendent world; or to be worse than worst Of those that lawless and incertain thought Imagine howling-'tis too horrible. The weariest and most loathed worldly life That age, ache, penury, and imprisonment Can lay on nature is a paradise To what we fear of death.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Alas, alas!

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Sweet sister, let me live. What sin you do to save a brother's life, Nature dispenses with the deed so far That it becomes a virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, you beast! O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch! Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice? Is't not a kind of incest to take life From thine own sister's shame? What should I think? Heaven shield my mother played my father fair, For such a warped slip of wilderness Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance, Die, perish! Might but my bending down Reprieve thee from thy fate, it should proceed. I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death, No word to save thee.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Nay, hear me, Isabel.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O fie, fie, fie! Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade. Mercy to thee would prove itself a bawd. 'Tis best that thou diest quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: O, hear me, Isabella.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Vouchsafe a word, young sister, but one word.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: What is your will?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Might you dispense with your leisure, I would by and by have some speech with you. The satisfaction I would require is likewise your own benefit.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I have no superfluous leisure, my stay must be stolen out of other affairs, but I will attend you a while.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Son, I have overheard what hath passed between you and your sister. Angelo had never the purpose to corrupt her; only he hath made an assay of her virtue, to practise his judgement with the disposition of natures. She, having the truth of honour in her, hath made him that gracious denial which he is most glad to receive. I am confessor to Angelo, and I know this to be true; therefore prepare yourself to death. Do not satisfy your resolution with hopes that are fallible. Tomorrow you must die; go to your knees and make ready.

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: Let me ask my sister pardon. I am so out of love with life that I will sue to be rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Hold you there. Farewell. Provost, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: What's your will, father?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: That, now you are come, you will be gone. Leave me a while with the maid; my mind promises with my habit no loss shall touch her by my company.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: In good time.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The hand that hath made you fair hath made you good. The goodness that is cheap in beauty makes beauty brief in goodness; but grace, being the soul of your complexion, shall keep the body of it ever fair. The assault that Angelo hath made to you, fortune hath conveyed to my understanding; and, but that frailty hath examples for his falling, I should wonder at Angelo. How will you do to content this substitute, and to save your brother?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I am now going to resolve him. I had rather my brother die by the law than my son should be unlawfully born. But, O, how much is the good Duke deceived in Angelo! If ever he return, and I can speak to him, I will open my lips in vain, or discover his government.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: That shall not be much amiss. Yet, as the matter now stands, he will avoid your accusation: he made trial of you only. Therefore fasten your ear on my advisings, to the love I have in doing good, a remedy presents itself. I do make myself believe that you may most uprighteously do a poor wronged lady a merited benefit; redeem your brother from the angry law; do no stain to your own gracious person; and much please the absent Duke, if peradventure he shall ever return to have hearing of this business.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Let me hear you speak farther. I have spirit to do anything that appears not foul in the truth of my spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Virtue is bold, and goodness never fearful. Have you not heard speak of Mariana, the sister of Frederick, the great soldier who miscarried at sea?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I have heard of the lady, and good words went with her name.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: She should this Angelo have married, was affianced to her oath, and the nuptial appointed. Between which time of the contract and limit of the solemnity, her brother Frederick was wrecked at sea, having in that perished vessel the dowry of his sister. But mark how heavily this befell to the poor gentlewoman. There she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his love toward her ever most kind and natural; with him, the portion and sinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry; with both, her combinate husband, this well-seeming Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Can this be so? Did Angelo so leave her?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Left her in her tears, and dried not one of them with his comfort, swallowed his vows whole, pretending in her discoveries of dishonour; in few, bestowed her on her own lamentation, which she yet wears for his sake; and he, a marble to her tears, is washed with them, but relents not.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: What a merit were it in death to take this poor maid from the world! What corruption in this life, that it will let this man live! But how out of this can she avail?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is a rupture that you may easily heal, and the cure of it not only saves your brother, but keeps you from dishonour in doing it.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Show me how, good father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This forenamed maid hath yet in her the continuance of her first affection. His unjust unkindness, that in all reason should have quenched her love, hath, like an impediment in the current, made it more violent and unruly. Go you to Angelo; answer his requiring with a plausible obedience; agree with his demands to the point. Only refer yourself to this advantage: first, that your stay with him may not be long; that the time may have all shadow and silence in it; and the place answer to convenience. This being granted in course, and now follows all. We shall advise this wronged maid to stead up your appointment, go in your place. If the encounter acknowledge itself hereafter, it may compel him to her recompense; and here, by this, is your brother saved, your honour untainted, the poor Mariana advantaged, and the corrupt deputy scaled. The maid will I frame and make fit for his attempt. If you think well to carry this as you may, the doubleness of the benefit defends the deceit from reproof. What think you of it?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: The image of it gives me content already, and I trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It lies much in your holding up. Haste you speedily to Angelo; if for this night he entreat you to his bed, give him promise of satisfaction. I will presently to Saint Luke's; there at the moated grange resides this dejected Mariana. At that place call upon me; and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I thank you for this comfort. Fare you well, good father.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you will needs buy and sell men and women like beasts, we shall have all the world drink brown and white bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O heavens, what stuff is here?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: 'Twas never merry world since, of two usuries, the merriest was put down, and the worser allowed by order of law a furred gown to keep him warm; and furred with fox on lambskins too, to signify that craft, being richer than innocency, stands for the facing.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Come your way, sir.-Bless you, good father friar.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And you, good brother father. What offence hath this man made you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, he hath offended the law; and, sir, we take him to be a thief too, sir; for we have found upon him, sir, a strange picklock, which we have sent to the deputy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Fie, sirrah, a bawd, a wicked bawd; The evil that thou causest to be done, That is thy means to live. Do thou but think What 'tis to cram a maw or clothe a back From such a filthy vice. Say to thyself, From their abominable and beastly touches I drink, I eat, array myself, and live. Canst thou believe thy living is a life, So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Indeed, it does stink in some sort, sir. But yet, sir, I would prove-

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Nay, if the devil have given thee proofs for sin, Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer. Correction and instruction must both work Ere this rude beast will profit.

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: He must before the deputy, sir; he has given him warning. The deputy cannot abide a whoremaster. If he be a whoremonger and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: That we were all, as some would seem to be, Free from our faults, as faults from seeming, free!

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: His neck will come to your waist-a cord, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I spy comfort, I cry bail! Here's a gentleman, and a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: How now, noble Pompey? What, at the wheels of Caesar? Art thou led in triumph? What, is there none of Pygmalion's images, newly made woman, to be had now, for putting the hand in the pocket and extracting it clutched? What reply, ha? What say'st thou to this tune, matter, and method? Is't not drowned i' th' last rain, ha? What say'st thou, trot? Is the world as it was, man? Which is the way? Is it sad and few words? Or how? The trick of it?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Still thus, and thus; still worse!
