dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: How doth my dear morsel, thy mistress? Procures she still, ha?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Troth, sir, she hath eaten up all her beef, and she is herself in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis good. It is the right of it. It must be so. Ever your fresh whore and your powdered bawd; an unshunned consequence; it must be so. Art going to prison, Pompey?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Yes, faith, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis not amiss, Pompey. Farewell. Go, say I sent thee thither. For debt, Pompey? Or how?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: For being a bawd, for being a bawd.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Well, then, imprison him. If imprisonment be the due of a bawd, why, 'tis his right. Bawd is he doubtless, and of antiquity, too. Bawd born. Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison, Pompey. You will turn good husband now, Pompey; you will keep the house.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I hope, sir, your good worship will be my bail.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: No, indeed, will I not, Pompey; it is not the wear. I will pray, Pompey, to increase your bondage. If you take it not patiently, why, your mettle is the more. Adieu, trusty Pompey.-Bless you, friar.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Come your ways, sir, come.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: You will not bail me then, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Then, Pompey, nor now.-What news abroad, friar? What news?

dialogues.speaker: Elbow
dialogues.line: Come your ways, sir, come.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Go to kennel, Pompey, go. What news, friar, of the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I know none. Can you tell me of any?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia; other some, he is in Rome. But where is he, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I know not where, but wheresoever, I wish him well.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: It was a mad fantastical trick of him to steal from the state and usurp the beggary he was never born to. Lord Angelo dukes it well in his absence. He puts transgression to't.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He does well in't.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: A little more lenity to lechery would do no harm in him. Something too crabbed that way, friar.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is too general a vice, and severity must cure it.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Yes, in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied; but it is impossible to extirp it quite, friar, till eating and drinking be put down. They say this Angelo was not made by man and woman after this downright way of creation. Is it true, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How should he be made, then?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Some report a sea-maid spawned him; some, that he was begot between two stockfishes. But it is certain that when he makes water, his urine is congealed ice; that I know to be true. And he is a motion ungenerative; that's infallible.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You are pleasant, sir, and speak apace.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Why, what a ruthless thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a codpiece to take away the life of a man! Would the Duke that is absent have done this? Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a hundred bastards, he would have paid for the nursing a thousand. He had some feeling of the sport; he knew the service, and that instructed him to mercy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I never heard the absent Duke much detected for women; he was not inclined that way.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: O, sir, you are deceived.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: 'Tis not possible.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Who, not the Duke? Yes, your beggar of fifty; and his use was to put a ducat in her clack-dish. The Duke had crotchets in him. He would be drunk too, that let me inform you.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You do him wrong, surely.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Sir, I was an inward of his. A shy fellow was the Duke; and I believe I know the cause of his withdrawing.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What, I prithee, might be the cause?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: No, pardon. 'Tis a secret must be locked within the teeth and the lips. But this I can let you understand: the greater file of the subject held the Duke to be wise.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Wise? Why, no question but he was.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: A very superficial, ignorant, unweighing fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Either this is envy in you, folly, or mistaking. The very stream of his life, and the business he hath helmed, must upon a warranted need give him a better proclamation. Let him be but testimonied in his own bringings-forth, and he shall appear to the envious a scholar, a statesman, and a soldier. Therefore you speak unskilfully. Or, if your knowledge be more, it is much darkened in your malice.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Sir, I know him, and I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Love talks with better knowledge, and knowledge with dearer love.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Come, sir, I know what I know.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I can hardly believe that, since you know not what you speak. But, if ever the Duke return, as our prayers are he may, let me desire you to make your answer before him. If it be honest you have spoke, you have courage to maintain it. I am bound to call upon you, and I pray you your name?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Sir, my name is Lucio, well known to the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He shall know you better, sir, if I may live to report you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I fear you not.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, you hope the Duke will return no more; or you imagine me too unhurtful an opposite. But indeed, I can do you little harm. You'll forswear this again.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I'll be hanged first! Thou art deceived in me, friar. But no more of this. Canst thou tell if Claudio die tomorrow or no?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why should he die, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Why? For filling a bottle with a tun-dish. I would the Duke we talk of were returned again. This ungenitured agent will unpeople the province with continency. Sparrows must not build in his house-eaves because they are lecherous. The Duke yet would have dark deeds darkly answered. He would never bring them to light. Would he were returned! Marry, this Claudio is condemned for untrussing. Farewell, good friar, I prithee pray for me. The Duke, I say to thee again, would eat mutton on Fridays. He's now past it; yet, and, I say to thee, he would mouth with a beggar though she smelt brown bread and garlic. Say that I said so. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: No might nor greatness in mortality Can censure 'scape. Back-wounding calumny The whitest virtue strikes. What king so strong Can tie the gall up in the slanderous tongue? But who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Go, away with her to prison.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: Good my lord, be good to me. Your honour is accounted a merciful man, good my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in the same kind? This would make mercy swear and play the tyrant.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: A bawd of eleven years' continuance, may it please your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Bawd
dialogues.line: My lord, this is one Lucio's information against me. Mistress Kate Keepdown was with child by him in the Duke's time; he promised her marriage. His child is a year and a quarter old come Philip and Jacob. I have kept it myself; and see how he goes about to abuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: That fellow is a fellow of much license. Let him be called before us. Away with her to prison. Go to, no more words. Provost, my brother Angelo will not be altered; Claudio must die tomorrow. Let him be furnished with divines, and have all charitable preparation. If my brother wrought by my pity, it should not be so with him.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: So please you, this friar hath been with him, and advised him for th' entertainment of death.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Good even, good father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Bliss and goodness on you!

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Of whence are you?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Not of this country, though my chance is now To use it for my time. I am a brother Of gracious order, late come from the See In special business from his Holiness.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: What news abroad i' th' world?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: None, but that there is so great a fever on goodness that the dissolution of it must cure it. Novelty is only in request, and as it is as dangerous to be aged in any kind of course as it is virtuous to be constant in any undertaking. There is scarce truth enough alive to make societies secure; but security enough to make fellowships accursed. Much upon this riddle runs the wisdom of the world. This news is old enough, yet it is every day's news. I pray you, sir, of what disposition was the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: One that, above all other strifes, contended especially to know himself.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What pleasure was he given to?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Rather rejoicing to see another merry, than merry at anything which professed to make him rejoice. A gentleman of all temperance. But leave we him to his events, with a prayer they may prove prosperous, and let me desire to know how you find Claudio prepared. I am made to understand that you have lent him visitation.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He professes to have received no sinister measure from his judge, but most willingly humbles himself to the determination of justice. Yet had he framed to himself, by the instruction of his frailty, many deceiving promises of life, which I, by my good leisure, have discredited to him, and now he is resolved to die.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: You have paid the heavens your function, and the prisoner the very debt of your calling. I have laboured for the poor gentleman to the extremest shore of my modesty, but my brother justice have I found so severe that he hath forced me to tell him he is indeed Justice.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: If his own life answer the straitness of his proceeding, it shall become him well; wherein if he chance to fail, he hath sentenced himself.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I am going to visit the prisoner. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Peace be with you. He who the sword of heaven will bear Should be as holy as severe, Pattern in himself to know, Grace to stand, and virtue go; More nor less to others paying Than by self-offences weighing. Shame to him whose cruel striking Kills for faults of his own liking! Twice treble shame on Angelo, To weed my vice, and let his grow! O, what may man within him hide, Though angel on the outward side! How may likeness, made in crimes, Make practice on the times, To draw with idle spiders' strings Most ponderous and substantial things! Craft against vice I must apply. With Angelo tonight shall lie His old betrothed but despised. So disguise shall, by th' disguised, Pay with falsehood false exacting, And perform an old contracting.

dialogues.speaker: Song
dialogues.line: _  Take, O take those lips away, That so sweetly were forsworn, And those eyes, the break of day, Lights that do mislead the morn. But my kisses bring again, Bring again; Seals of love, but sealed in vain, Sealed in vain._

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Break off thy song, and haste thee quick away; Here comes a man of comfort, whose advice Hath often stilled my brawling discontent. I cry you mercy, sir, and well could wish You had not found me here so musical. Let me excuse me, and believe me so, My mirth it much displeased, but pleased my woe.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: 'Tis good; though music oft hath such a charm To make bad good and good provoke to harm. I pray you tell me, hath anybody inquired for me here today? Much upon this time have I promised here to meet.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: You have not been inquired after. I have sat here all day.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I do constantly believe you. The time is come even now. I shall crave your forbearance a little. Maybe I will call upon you anon for some advantage to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: I am always bound to you.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Very well met, and welcome. What is the news from this good deputy?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: He hath a garden circummured with brick, Whose western side is with a vineyard backed; And to that vineyard is a planched gate That makes his opening with this bigger key. This other doth command a little door Which from the vineyard to the garden leads; There have I made my promise, upon the Heavy middle of the night to call on him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But shall you on your knowledge find this way?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I have ta'en a due and wary note upon't; With whispering and most guilty diligence, In action all of precept, he did show me The way twice o'er.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Are there no other tokens Between you 'greed concerning her observance?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: No, none, but only a repair i' th' dark, And that I have possessed him my most stay Can be but brief, for I have made him know I have a servant comes with me along, That stays upon me; whose persuasion is I come about my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: 'Tis well borne up. I have not yet made known to Mariana A word of this.-What ho, within! Come forth. I pray you be acquainted with this maid; She comes to do you good.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I do desire the like.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Good friar, I know you do, and have found it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Take, then, this your companion by the hand, Who hath a story ready for your ear. I shall attend your leisure; but make haste. The vaporous night approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Will't please you walk aside?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O place and greatness, millions of false eyes Are stuck upon thee; volumes of report Run with these false, and most contrarious quest Upon thy doings; thousand escapes of wit Make thee the father of their idle dream And rack thee in their fancies. Welcome; how agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: She'll take the enterprise upon her, father, If you advise it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is not my consent, But my entreaty too.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Little have you to say When you depart from him, but, soft and low, "Remember now my brother."

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Fear me not.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Nor, gentle daughter, fear you not at all. He is your husband on a pre-contract. To bring you thus together 'tis no sin, Sith that the justice of your title to him Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go; Our corn's to reap, for yet our tithe's to sow.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Come hither, sirrah. Can you cut off a man's head?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: If the man be a bachelor, sir, I can; but if he be a married man, he's his wife's head, and I can never cut off a woman's head.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Come, sir, leave me your snatches, and yield me a direct answer. Tomorrow morning are to die Claudio and Barnardine. Here is in our prison a common executioner, who in his office lacks a helper; if you will take it on you to assist him, it shall redeem you from your gyves; if not, you shall have your full time of imprisonment, and your deliverance with an unpitied whipping; for you have been a notorious bawd.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, I have been an unlawful bawd time out of mind, but yet I will be content to be a lawful hangman. I would be glad to receive some instruction from my fellow-partner.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: What ho, Abhorson! Where's Abhorson, there?

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Do you call, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Sirrah, here's a fellow will help you tomorrow in your execution. If you think it meet, compound with him by the year, and let him abide here with you; if not, use him for the present, and dismiss him. He cannot plead his estimation with you; he hath been a bawd.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: A bawd, sir? Fie upon him, he will discredit our mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Go to, sir; you weigh equally. A feather will turn the scale.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Pray, sir, by your good favour-for surely, sir, a good favour you have, but that you have a hanging look-do you call, sir, your occupation a mystery?

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, a mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Painting, sir, I have heard say, is a mystery; and your whores, sir, being members of my occupation, using painting, do prove my occupation a mystery. But what mystery there should be in hanging, if I should be hanged, I cannot imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Sir, it is a mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Proof.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Every true man's apparel fits your thief. If it be too little for your thief, your true man thinks it big enough; if it be too big for your thief, your thief thinks it little enough. So every true man's apparel fits your thief.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Are you agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sir, I will serve him; for I do find your hangman is a more penitent trade than your bawd. He doth oftener ask forgiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: You, sirrah, provide your block and your axe tomorrow four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Come on, bawd. I will instruct thee in my trade. Follow.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I do desire to learn, sir; and I hope, if you have occasion to use me for your own turn, you shall find me yare. For truly, sir, for your kindness I owe you a good turn.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Call hither Barnardine and Claudio. Th' one has my pity; not a jot the other, Being a murderer, though he were my brother. Look, here's the warrant, Claudio, for thy death. 'Tis now dead midnight, and by eight tomorrow Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?

dialogues.speaker: Claudio
dialogues.line: As fast locked up in sleep as guiltless labour When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones. He will not wake.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Who can do good on him? Well, go, prepare yourself.  But hark, what noise? Heaven give your spirits comfort! By and by!- I hope it is some pardon or reprieve For the most gentle Claudio. Welcome, father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The best and wholesom'st spirits of the night Envelop you, good Provost! Who called here of late?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: None, since the curfew rung.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Not Isabel?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: They will then, ere't be long.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: What comfort is for Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There's some in hope.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: It is a bitter deputy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Not so, not so. His life is paralleled Even with the stroke and line of his great justice. He doth with holy abstinence subdue That in himself which he spurs on his power To qualify in others. Were he mealed with that Which he corrects, then were he tyrannous; But this being so, he's just. Now are they come. This is a gentle provost. Seldom when The steeled gaoler is the friend of men. How now? What noise? That spirit's possessed with haste That wounds th' unsisting postern with these strokes. Provost returns.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: There he must stay until the officer Arise to let him in. He is called up.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Have you no countermand for Claudio yet, But he must die tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: None, sir, none.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: As near the dawning, Provost, as it is, You shall hear more ere morning.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Happily You something know, yet I believe there comes No countermand. No such example have we. Besides, upon the very siege of justice Lord Angelo hath to the public ear Professed the contrary. This is his Lordship's man.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And here comes Claudio's pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord hath sent you this note, and by me this further charge: that you swerve not from the smallest article of it, neither in time, matter, or other circumstance. Good morrow; for, as I take it, it is almost day.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I shall obey him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This is his pardon, purchased by such sin For which the pardoner himself is in. Hence hath offence his quick celerity, When it is borne in high authority. When vice makes mercy, mercy's so extended That for the fault's love is th' offender friended. Now, sir, what news?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I told you: Lord Angelo, belike thinking me remiss in mine office, awakens me with this unwonted putting-on; methinks strangely, for he hath not used it before.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Pray you, let's hear.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: _Whatsoever you may hear to the contrary, let Claudio be executed by four of the clock, and in the afternoon, Barnardine. For my better satisfaction, let me have Claudio's head sent me by five. Let this be duly performed, with a thought that more depends on it than we must yet deliver. Thus fail not to do your office, as you will answer it at your peril._ What say you to this, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What is that Barnardine who is to be executed in th' afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: A Bohemian born, but here nursed up and bred; one that is a prisoner nine years old.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How came it that the absent Duke had not either delivered him to his liberty, or executed him? I have heard it was ever his manner to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: His friends still wrought reprieves for him; and indeed, his fact till now in the government of Lord Angelo, came not to an undoubtful proof.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is now apparent?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Most manifest, and not denied by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Hath he borne himself penitently in prison? How seems he to be touched?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: A man that apprehends death no more dreadfully but as a drunken sleep; careless, reckless, and fearless of what's past, present, or to come; insensible of mortality and desperately mortal.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He wants advice.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: He will hear none. He hath evermore had the liberty of the prison; give him leave to escape hence, he would not. Drunk many times a day, if not many days entirely drunk. We have very oft awaked him, as if to carry him to execution, and showed him a seeming warrant for it. It hath not moved him at all.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: More of him anon. There is written in your brow, Provost, honesty and constancy; if I read it not truly, my ancient skill beguiles me. But in the boldness of my cunning I will lay myself in hazard. Claudio, whom here you have warrant to execute, is no greater forfeit to the law than Angelo who hath sentenced him. To make you understand this in a manifested effect, I crave but four days' respite, for the which you are to do me both a present and a dangerous courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Pray, sir, in what?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: In the delaying death.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Alack, how may I do it? Having the hour limited, and an express command, under penalty, to deliver his head in the view of Angelo? I may make my case as Claudio's, to cross this in the smallest.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: By the vow of mine order, I warrant you, if my instructions may be your guide. Let this Barnardine be this morning executed, and his head borne to Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Angelo hath seen them both, and will discover the favour.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, death's a great disguiser, and you may add to it. Shave the head and tie the beard, and say it was the desire of the penitent to be so bared before his death. You know the course is common. If anything fall to you upon this, more than thanks and good fortune, by the saint whom I profess, I will plead against it with my life.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Pardon me, good father; it is against my oath.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Were you sworn to the Duke, or to the Deputy?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: To him and to his substitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You will think you have made no offence if the Duke avouch the justice of your dealing?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: But what likelihood is in that?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Not a resemblance, but a certainty. Yet since I see you fearful, that neither my coat, integrity, nor persuasion, can with ease attempt you, I will go further than I meant, to pluck all fears out of you. Look you, sir, here is the hand and seal of the Duke. You know the character, I doubt not, and the signet is not strange to you.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I know them both.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The contents of this is the return of the Duke; you shall anon over-read it at your pleasure, where you shall find within these two days he will be here. This is a thing that Angelo knows not; for he this very day receives letters of strange tenour, perchance of the Duke's death, perchance entering into some monastery; but, by chance, nothing of what is writ. Look, th' unfolding star calls up the shepherd. Put not yourself into amazement how these things should be. All difficulties are but easy when they are known. Call your executioner, and off with Barnardine's head. I will give him a present shrift, and advise him for a better place. Yet you are amazed; but this shall absolutely resolve you. Come away; it is almost clear dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I am as well acquainted here as I was in our house of profession. One would think it were Mistress Overdone's own house, for here be many of her old customers. First, here's young Master Rash; he's in for a commodity of brown paper and old ginger, nine score and seventeen pounds; of which he made five marks ready money. Marry, then ginger was not much in request, for the old women were all dead. Then is there here one Master Caper, at the suit of Master Three-pile the mercer, for some four suits of peach-coloured satin, which now peaches him a beggar. Then have we here young Dizie, and young Master Deep-vow, and Master Copperspur, and Master Starve-lackey, the rapier and dagger man, and young Drop-heir that killed lusty Pudding, and Master Forthright the tilter, and brave Master Shoe-tie the great traveller, and wild Half-can that stabbed Pots, and I think forty more, all great doers in our trade, and are now "for the Lord's sake."

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hither.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Master Barnardine! You must rise and be hanged, Master Barnardine.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: What ho, Barnardine!

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: A pox o' your throats! Who makes that noise there? What are you?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Your friends, sir; the hangman. You must be so good, sir, to rise and be put to death.

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: Away, you rogue, away; I am sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Tell him he must awake, and that quickly too.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Pray, Master Barnardine, awake till you are executed, and sleep afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: He is coming, sir, he is coming. I hear his straw rustle.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Is the axe upon the block, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Very ready, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: How now, Abhorson? What's the news with you?

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, I would desire you to clap into your prayers; for, look you, the warrant's come.

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: You rogue, I have been drinking all night; I am not fitted for't.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: O, the better, sir; for he that drinks all night and is hanged betimes in the morning may sleep the sounder all the next day.

dialogues.speaker: Abhorson
dialogues.line: Look you, sir, here comes your ghostly father. Do we jest now, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir, induced by my charity, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I am come to advise you, comfort you, and pray with you.

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: Friar, not I. I have been drinking hard all night, and I will have more time to prepare me, or they shall beat out my brains with billets. I will not consent to die this day, that's certain.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, sir, you must; and therefore I beseech you Look forward on the journey you shall go.

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: I swear I will not die today for any man's persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But hear you-

dialogues.speaker: Barnardine
dialogues.line: Not a word. If you have anything to say to me, come to my ward, for thence will not I today.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Unfit to live or die. O gravel heart! After him, fellows; bring him to the block.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Now, sir, how do you find the prisoner?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: A creature unprepared, unmeet for death; And to transport him in the mind he is Were damnable.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Here in the prison, father, There died this morning of a cruel fever One Ragozine, a most notorious pirate, A man of Claudio's years; his beard and head Just of his colour. What if we do omit This reprobate till he were well inclined, And satisfy the Deputy with the visage Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, 'tis an accident that heaven provides! Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on Prefixed by Angelo. See this be done, And sent according to command, whiles I Persuade this rude wretch willingly to die.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: This shall be done, good father, presently. But Barnardine must die this afternoon; And how shall we continue Claudio, To save me from the danger that might come If he were known alive?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Let this be done: Put them in secret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio. Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting To yonder generation, you shall find Your safety manifested.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I am your free dependant.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Quick, dispatch, and send the head to Angelo. Now will I write letters to Angelo, The Provost, he shall bear them, whose contents Shall witness to him I am near at home; And that by great injunctions I am bound To enter publicly. Him I'll desire To meet me at the consecrated fount, A league below the city; and from thence, By cold gradation and well-balanced form. We shall proceed with Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Here is the head; I'll carry it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Convenient is it. Make a swift return; For I would commune with you of such things That want no ear but yours.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: I'll make all speed.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Peace, ho, be here!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The tongue of Isabel. She's come to know If yet her brother's pardon be come hither. But I will keep her ignorant of her good, To make her heavenly comforts of despair When it is least expected.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Ho, by your leave!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Good morning to you, fair and gracious daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: The better, given me by so holy a man. Hath yet the Deputy sent my brother's pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He hath released him, Isabel, from the world. His head is off, and sent to Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Nay, but it is not so.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is no other. Show your wisdom, daughter, in your close patience.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, I will to him and pluck out his eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You shall not be admitted to his sight.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Unhappy Claudio! Wretched Isabel! Injurious world! Most damned Angelo!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This nor hurts him nor profits you a jot. Forbear it, therefore; give your cause to heaven. Mark what I say, which you shall find By every syllable a faithful verity. The Duke comes home tomorrow;-nay, dry your eyes. One of our convent, and his confessor, Gives me this instance. Already he hath carried Notice to Escalus and Angelo, Who do prepare to meet him at the gates, There to give up their power. If you can, pace your wisdom In that good path that I would wish it go, And you shall have your bosom on this wretch, Grace of the Duke, revenges to your heart, And general honour.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I am directed by you.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This letter, then, to Friar Peter give; 'Tis that he sent me of the Duke's return. Say, by this token, I desire his company At Mariana's house tonight. Her cause and yours I'll perfect him withal, and he shall bring you Before the Duke; and to the head of Angelo Accuse him home and home. For my poor self, I am combined by a sacred vow, And shall be absent. Wend you with this letter. Command these fretting waters from your eyes With a light heart; trust not my holy order, If I pervert your course.-Who's here?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Good even. Friar, where is the Provost?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Not within, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: O pretty Isabella, I am pale at mine heart to see thine eyes so red. Thou must be patient. I am fain to dine and sup with water and bran. I dare not for my head fill my belly. One fruitful meal would set me to't. But they say the Duke will be here tomorrow. By my troth, Isabel, I loved thy brother. If the old fantastical duke of dark corners had been at home, he had lived.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir, the Duke is marvellous little beholding to your reports; but the best is, he lives not in them.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Friar, thou knowest not the Duke so well as I do. He's a better woodman than thou tak'st him for.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Well, you'll answer this one day. Fare ye well.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Nay, tarry, I'll go along with thee. I can tell thee pretty tales of the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You have told me too many of him already, sir, if they be true; if not true, none were enough.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I was once before him for getting a wench with child.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Did you such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Yes, marry, did I; but I was fain to forswear it. They would else have married me to the rotten medlar.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir, your company is fairer than honest. Rest you well.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: By my troth, I'll go with thee to the lane's end. If bawdy talk offend you, we'll have very little of it. Nay, friar, I am a kind of burr; I shall stick.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: In most uneven and distracted manner. His actions show much like to madness; pray heaven his wisdom be not tainted. And why meet him at the gates and redeliver our authorities there?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: And why should we proclaim it in an hour before his entering, that if any crave redress of injustice, they should exhibit their petitions in the street?

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: He shows his reason for that: to have a dispatch of complaints, and to deliver us from devices hereafter, which shall then have no power to stand against us.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Well, I beseech you, let it be proclaimed. Betimes i' th' morn I'll call you at your house. Give notice to such men of sort and suit As are to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I shall, sir. Fare you well.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Good night. This deed unshapes me quite, makes me unpregnant And dull to all proceedings. A deflowered maid; And by an eminent body that enforced The law against it! But that her tender shame Will not proclaim against her maiden loss, How might she tongue me! Yet reason dares her no, For my authority bears so credent bulk That no particular scandal once can touch But it confounds the breather. He should have lived, Save that his riotous youth, with dangerous sense, Might in the times to come have ta'en revenge By so receiving a dishonoured life With ransom of such shame. Would yet he had lived. Alack, when once our grace we have forgot, Nothing goes right; we would, and we would not.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: These letters at fit time deliver me. The Provost knows our purpose and our plot. The matter being afoot, keep your instruction And hold you ever to our special drift, Though sometimes you do blench from this to that As cause doth minister. Go call at Flavius' house, And tell him where I stay. Give the like notice To Valencius, Rowland, and to Crassus, And bid them bring the trumpets to the gate. But send me Flavius first.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: It shall be speeded well.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I thank thee, Varrius, thou hast made good haste. Come, we will walk. There's other of our friends Will greet us here anon. My gentle Varrius.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: To speak so indirectly I am loath; I would say the truth, but to accuse him so That is your part; yet I am advised to do it, He says, to veil full purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Be ruled by him.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Besides, he tells me that, if peradventure He speak against me on the adverse side, I should not think it strange, for 'tis a physic That's bitter to sweet end.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: I would Friar Peter-

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, peace, the friar is come.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: Come, I have found you out a stand most fit, Where you may have such vantage on the Duke He shall not pass you. Twice have the trumpets sounded. The generous and gravest citizens Have hent the gates, and very near upon The Duke is entering. Therefore hence, away.

scenes.location: A public place near the city gate.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: My very worthy cousin, fairly met. Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you. ANGELO and ESCALUS. Happy return be to your royal grace!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Many and hearty thankings to you both. We have made inquiry of you, and we hear Such goodness of your justice that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, Forerunning more requital.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: You make my bonds still greater.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, your desert speaks loud, and I should wrong it To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, When it deserves with characters of brass A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time And rasure of oblivion. Give me your hand And let the subject see, to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favours that keep within.-Come, Escalus, You must walk by us on our other hand. And good supporters are you.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: Now is your time. Speak loud, and kneel before him.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Justice, O royal Duke! Vail your regard Upon a wronged-I would fain have said, a maid. O worthy prince, dishonour not your eye By throwing it on any other object Till you have heard me in my true complaint, And given me justice, justice, justice, justice!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Relate your wrongs. In what? By whom? Be brief. Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice. Reveal yourself to him.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O worthy Duke, You bid me seek redemption of the devil. Hear me yourself, for that which I must speak Must either punish me, not being believed, Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm. She hath been a suitor to me for her brother, Cut off by course of justice.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: By course of justice!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Most strange, but yet most truly will I speak. That Angelo's forsworn, is it not strange? That Angelo's a murderer, is't not strange? That Angelo is an adulterous thief, An hypocrite, a virgin-violator, Is it not strange and strange?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Nay, it is ten times strange.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: It is not truer he is Angelo Than this is all as true as it is strange. Nay, it is ten times true, for truth is truth To th' end of reckoning.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Away with her. Poor soul, She speaks this in th' infirmity of sense.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O Prince, I conjure thee, as thou believ'st There is another comfort than this world, That thou neglect me not with that opinion That I am touched with madness. Make not impossible That which but seems unlike. 'Tis not impossible But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground, May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute, As Angelo; even so may Angelo, In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms, Be an arch-villain. Believe it, royal Prince, If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more, Had I more name for badness.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: By mine honesty, If she be mad, as I believe no other, Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense, Such a dependency of thing on thing, As e'er I heard in madness.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O gracious Duke, Harp not on that; nor do not banish reason For inequality; but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid, And hide the false seems true.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Many that are not mad Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I am the sister of one Claudio, Condemned upon the act of fornication To lose his head; condemned by Angelo. I, in probation of a sisterhood, Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio As then the messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: That's I, an't like your Grace. I came to her from Claudio and desired her To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo For her poor brother's pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: That's he, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You were not bid to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, Nor wished to hold my peace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I wish you now, then; Pray you take note of it; and when you have A business for yourself, pray heaven you then Be perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I warrant your honour.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The warrant's for yourself. Take heed to it.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It may be right, but you are i' the wrong To speak before your time.-Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I went To this pernicious caitiff deputy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: That's somewhat madly spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Pardon it; The phrase is to the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: In brief, to set the needless process by: How I persuaded, how I prayed and kneeled, How he refelled me, and how I replied- For this was of much length-the vile conclusion I now begin with grief and shame to utter. He would not, but by gift of my chaste body To his concupiscible intemperate lust, Release my brother; and after much debatement, My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, And I did yield to him. But the next morn betimes, His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant For my poor brother's head.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This is most likely!

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, that it were as like as it is true!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: By heaven, fond wretch, thou know'st not what thou speak'st, Or else thou art suborned against his honour In hateful practice. First, his integrity Stands without blemish; next, it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself. If he had so offended, He would have weighed thy brother by himself, And not have cut him off. Someone hath set you on. Confess the truth, and say by whose advice Thou cam'st here to complain.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: And is this all? Then, O you blessed ministers above, Keep me in patience, and with ripened time Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up In countenance! Heaven shield your Grace from woe, As I, thus wronged, hence unbelieved go.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I know you'd fain be gone. An officer! To prison with her! Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us? This needs must be a practice. Who knew of your intent and coming hither?

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: My lord, I know him. 'Tis a meddling friar. I do not like the man. Had he been lay, my lord, For certain words he spake against your Grace In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Words against me? This's a good friar, belike. And to set on this wretched woman here Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, I saw them at the prison. A saucy friar, A very scurvy fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: Blessed be your royal Grace! I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard Your royal ear abused. First hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute, Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: We did believe no less. Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: I know him for a man divine and holy, Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler, As he's reported by this gentleman; And, on my trust, a man that never yet Did, as he vouches, misreport your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: My lord, most villainously; believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: Well, he in time may come to clear himself; But at this instant he is sick, my lord, Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request, Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know Is true and false; and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman, To justify this worthy nobleman, So vulgarly and personally accused, Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes, Till she herself confess it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Good friar, let's hear it. Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo? O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools! Give us some seats.-Come, cousin Angelo, In this I'll be impartial. Be you judge Of your own cause. Is this the witness, friar? First let her show her face, and after speak.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face Until my husband bid me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What, are you married?

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: No, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Are you a maid?

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: No, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: A widow, then?

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Neither, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why, you are nothing then, neither maid, widow, nor wife?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Silence that fellow. I would he had some cause to prattle for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Well, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: My lord, I do confess I ne'er was married, And I confess besides, I am no maid. I have known my husband; yet my husband Knows not that ever he knew me.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: He was drunk, then, my lord; it can be no better.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Well, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Now I come to't, my lord. She that accuses him of fornication In self-same manner doth accuse my husband, And charges him, my lord, with such a time When I'll depose I had him in mine arms With all th' effect of love.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Charges she more than me?

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Not that I know.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: No? You say your husband.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, But knows, he thinks, that he knows Isabel's.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: My husband bids me; now I will unmask.  This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, Which once thou swor'st was worth the looking on. This is the hand which, with a vowed contract, Was fast belocked in thine. This is the body That took away the match from Isabel And did supply thee at thy garden-house In her imagined person.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Know you this woman?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Carnally, she says.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sirrah, no more.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Enough, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: My lord, I must confess I know this woman; And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off, Partly for that her promised proportions Came short of composition; but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity. Since which time of five years I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, Upon my faith and honour.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Noble Prince, As there comes light from heaven and words from breath, As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue, I am affianced this man's wife as strongly As words could make up vows. And, my good lord, But Tuesday night last gone, in's garden-house, He knew me as a wife. As this is true, Let me in safety raise me from my knees, Or else for ever be confixed here, A marble monument!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I did but smile till now. Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice. My patience here is touched. I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on. Let me have way, my lord, To find this practice out.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, with my heart; And punish them to your height of pleasure. Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman, Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths, Though they would swear down each particular saint, Were testimonies against his worth and credit, That's sealed in approbation? You, Lord Escalus, Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived. There is another friar that set them on; Let him be sent for.

dialogues.speaker: Friar Peter
dialogues.line: Would he were here, my lord; for he indeed Hath set the women on to this complaint. Your Provost knows the place where he abides, And he may fetch him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Go, do it instantly. And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin, Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth, Do with your injuries as seems you best In any chastisement. I for a while Will leave you; but stir not you till you have Well determined upon these slanderers.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: My lord, we'll do it throughly. Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: _Cucullus non facit monachum_, honest in nothing but in his clothes, and one that hath spoke most villainous speeches of the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come, and enforce them against him. We shall find this friar a notable fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: As any in Vienna, on my word.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Call that same Isabel here once again. I would speak with her. Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you shall see how I'll handle her.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Not better than he, by her own report.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Say you?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would sooner confess; perchance, publicly, she'll be ashamed. Officers.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I will go darkly to work with her.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: That's the way; for women are light at midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Come on, mistress, here's a gentlewoman denies all that you have said.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of, here with the Provost.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: In very good time. Speak not you to him till we call upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Mum.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Come, sir, did you set these women on to slander Lord Angelo? They have confessed you did.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: 'Tis false.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: How! Know you where you are?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Respect to your great place; and let the devil Be sometime honoured for his burning throne. Where is the Duke? 'Tis he should hear me speak.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: The Duke's in us; and we will hear you speak. Look you speak justly.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls, Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox, Good night to your redress! Is the Duke gone? Then is your cause gone too. The Duke's unjust Thus to retort your manifest appeal, And put your trial in the villain's mouth Which here you come to accuse.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Why, thou unreverend and unhallowed friar, Is't not enough thou hast suborned these women To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth, And in the witness of his proper ear, To call him villain? And then to glance from him To th' Duke himself, to tax him with injustice? Take him hence! To th' rack with him! We'll touse you Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose. What! Unjust?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be not so hot. The Duke Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he Dare rack his own. His subject am I not, Nor here provincial. My business in this state Made me a looker-on here in Vienna, Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble Till it o'errun the stew. Laws for all faults, But faults so countenanced that the strong statutes Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, As much in mock as mark.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio? Is this the man that you did tell us of?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman Baldpate. Do you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice. I met you at the prison, in the absence of the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: O did you so? And do you remember what you said of the Duke?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Most notedly, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Do you so, sir? And was the Duke a fleshmonger, a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You must, sir, change persons with me ere you make that my report. You indeed spoke so of him, and much more, much worse.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the nose for thy speeches?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I protest I love the Duke as I love myself.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: Hark how the villain would close now, after his treasonable abuses!

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away with him to prison! Where is the provost? Away with him to prison! Lay bolts enough upon him. Let him speak no more. Away with those giglets too, and with the other confederate companion!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Stay, sir, stay a while.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: What, resists he? Help him, Lucio.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Come, sir, come, sir, come, sir. Foh, sir! Why, you bald-pated lying rascal! You must be hooded, must you? Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you! Show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour! Will't not off?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Thou art the first knave that e'er mad'st a duke. First, Provost, let me bail these gentle three.  Sneak not away, sir, for the friar and you Must have a word anon.-Lay hold on him.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: This may prove worse than hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What you have spoke I pardon. Sit you down. We'll borrow place of him.  Sir, by your leave. Hast thou or word, or wit, or impudence, That yet can do thee office? If thou hast, Rely upon it till my tale be heard, And hold no longer out.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: O my dread lord, I should be guiltier than my guiltiness To think I can be undiscernible, When I perceive your Grace, like power divine, Hath looked upon my passes. Then, good Prince, No longer session hold upon my shame, But let my trial be mine own confession. Immediate sentence then, and sequent death Is all the grace I beg.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Come hither, Mariana. Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I was, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Go, take her hence and marry her instantly. Do you the office, friar; which consummate, Return him here again.-Go with him, Provost.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour Than at the strangeness of it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Come hither, Isabel. Your friar is now your prince. As I was then Advertising and holy to your business, Not changing heart with habit, I am still Attorneyed at your service.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: O, give me pardon, That I, your vassal, have employed and pained Your unknown sovereignty.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You are pardoned, Isabel. And now, dear maid, be you as free to us. Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart, And you may marvel why I obscured myself, Labouring to save his life, and would not rather Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid, It was the swift celerity of his death, Which I did think with slower foot came on, That brained my purpose. But peace be with him. That life is better life, past fearing death, Than that which lives to fear. Make it your comfort, So happy is your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: I do, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: For this new-married man approaching here, Whose salt imagination yet hath wronged Your well-defended honour, you must pardon For Mariana's sake. But as he adjudged your brother, Being criminal in double violation Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach Thereon dependent, for your brother's life, The very mercy of the law cries out Most audible, even from his proper tongue, "An Angelo for Claudio, death for death." Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure; Like doth quit like, and measure still for measure. Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested, Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage. We do condemn thee to the very block Where Claudio stooped to death, and with like haste. Away with him.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: O my most gracious lord, I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: It is your husband mocked you with a husband. Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, I thought your marriage fit. Else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life, And choke your good to come. For his possessions, Although by confiscation they are ours, We do instate and widow you with all To buy you a better husband.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: O my dear lord, I crave no other, nor no better man.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Never crave him; we are definitive.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Gentle my liege-

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You do but lose your labour. Away with him to death.  Now, sir, to you.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: O my good lord.-Sweet Isabel, take my part; Lend me your knees, and all my life to come I'll lend you all my life to do you service.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Against all sense you do importune her. Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact, Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, And take her hence in horror.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Isabel, Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me; Hold up your hands, say nothing. I'll speak all. They say best men are moulded out of faults, And, for the most, become much more the better For being a little bad. So may my husband. O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: He dies for Claudio's death.

dialogues.speaker: Isabella
dialogues.line: Most bounteous sir, Look, if it please you, on this man condemned As if my brother lived. I partly think A due sincerity governed his deeds Till he did look on me. Since it is so, Let him not die. My brother had but justice, In that he did the thing for which he died. For Angelo, His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, And must be buried but as an intent That perished by the way. Thoughts are no subjects; Intents but merely thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Mariana
dialogues.line: Merely, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Your suit's unprofitable. Stand up, I say. I have bethought me of another fault. Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded At an unusual hour?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: It was commanded so.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: No, my good lord, it was by private message.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: For which I do discharge you of your office. Give up your keys.

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: Pardon me, noble lord. I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; Yet did repent me after more advice. For testimony whereof, one in the prison That should by private order else have died, I have reserved alive.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What's he?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: His name is Barnardine.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio. Go fetch him hither, let me look upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Escalus
dialogues.line: I am sorry one so learned and so wise As you, Lord Angelo, have still appeared, Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood And lack of tempered judgement afterward.

dialogues.speaker: Angelo
dialogues.line: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure, And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart That I crave death more willingly than mercy; 'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it. Enter Provost with Barnardine, Claudio (muffled) and Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Which is that Barnardine?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: This, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There was a friar told me of this man. Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul That apprehends no further than this world, And squar'st thy life according. Thou'rt condemned; But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all, And pray thee take this mercy to provide For better times to come. Friar, advise him; I leave him to your hand.-What muffled fellow's that?

dialogues.speaker: Provost
dialogues.line: This is another prisoner that I saved, Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; As like almost to Claudio as himself.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: If he be like your brother, for his sake Is he pardoned; and for your lovely sake, Give me your hand and say you will be mine. He is my brother too. But fitter time for that. By this Lord Angelo perceives he's safe; Methinks I see a quick'ning in his eye. Well, Angelo, your evil quits you well. Look that you love your wife, her worth worth yours. I find an apt remission in myself. And yet here's one in place I cannot pardon.  You, sirrah, that knew me for a fool, a coward, One all of luxury, an ass, a madman. Wherein have I so deserved of you That you extol me thus?

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Faith, my lord, I spoke it but according to the trick. If you will hang me for it, you may, but I had rather it would please you I might be whipped.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Whipped first, sir, and hanged after. Proclaim it, Provost, round about the city, If any woman wronged by this lewd fellow, As I have heard him swear himself there's one Whom he begot with child-let her appear, And he shall marry her. The nuptial finished, Let him be whipped and hanged.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: I beseech your Highness, do not marry me to a whore. Your highness said even now I made you a duke; good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her. Thy slanders I forgive, and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits.-Take him to prison, And see our pleasure herein executed.

dialogues.speaker: Lucio
dialogues.line: Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death, whipping, and hanging.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Slandering a prince deserves it. She, Claudio, that you wronged, look you restore. Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo. I have confessed her, and I know her virtue. Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness; There's more behind that is more gratulate. Thanks, Provost, for thy care and secrecy; We shall employ thee in a worthier place. Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home The head of Ragozine for Claudio's. Th' offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel, I have a motion much imports your good; Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline, What's mine is yours, and what is yours is mine. So, bring us to our palace, where we'll show What's yet behind that's meet you all should know.
